THE NEWS.LETTER
VOL. XVI, NO. 4.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 30, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

NEW ATHLETIC POLICIES

DR. RENOUF IS MISSED

BASEBALL PROSPECTS BRIGHT

HOPKINS ROBBED OF VICTORY

Arguments in Favor of a Graduate
Manager, Press Agent and
Graduate Coaches.

President Remsen's Appreciation of
Former Collegiate Professor of
Physics Who Has Retired.

Attractive Schedule Being Arranged With
Big Northern Universities—Princeton and Yale to Come Here.

Touchdown Not Allowed to Count by
the Referee—Black and Blue
Men Played Well.

Dr. Edward Renouf, who has just
retired from active, service in the
University, has been a member of
our teaching staff since 1885. In
that year he came to us from Munich, where he had been an Assistant
in the chemical laboratory since
188o, under Baeyer and Volhard.
He was Assistant in Chemistry here
one year and was then made Associate. For six years he held this
title and was then appointed Collegiate Professor of Chemistry, which
position he held until his withdrawal
in 1911, a period of nineteen years.
During this time his relations with
the undergraduate students have
been especially close and his influence has probably been greater than
that of any other member of the
staff, except the Dean.
Dr. Renouf went to Germany at
an early age and studied at Heidelberg, Jena, and Munich. In 1868
he returned to the United States
and for a time worked at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
In a few years he went back to Germany and completed the work for
the degree of doctor of philosophy,
which degree was conferred upon
him by the University of Freiburg
in 1880.
At a meeting of the Board of Collegiate Studies of the Johns Hopkins University, held September 30,
1911, the following minute was
adopted:
"Since the meeting of this Board
in June, Dr. Edward Renouf, Collegiate Professor of Chemistry, has,
in consequence of ill health, retired
from the service of the University.
• "Dr. Renouf's connection with the
Johns Hopkins University extends
back almost to the beginning. As
the instructor of one of the most
numerous of our undergraduate
classes; as the adviser, each year,
of a large body of students; as a
member of the Executive Committee, giving much time and thought
to the duties incident to that position; as a member of the Committee
on the Gymnasium, and in that capacity called upon to advise and to
act in regard to many matters of
delicacy and difficulty; as conspicuously high-minded, conscientious,
and sympathetic in all his relations,
both with his pupils and with his
colleagues, Dr. Renouf has contributed much toward the maintenance of proper standards of feeling and conduct among our stu-

Although the lacrosse schedule
for next spring has been completed,
the baseball team has as yet not had
all its dates filled. Manager Meekins is to be congratulated on the
games which he has arranged, however, and it is to be hoped that he
will succeed in concluding negotiations for those which are pending.
The schedule to date is:
April 4—Princeton at Baltimore.
April 8 or 9—Yale at Baltimore.
April 24—Navy at Annapolis.
April 27—Western Maryland at
Baltimore.
May 18—St. John's at Baltimore.
The games which are under consideration are with Georgetown,
Harvard, the University of Pennsylvania, and the University of Virginia.
Hopkins is especially fortunate in
getting Princeton to come to Baltimore. Princeton had an unusually
strong team.last year, and will probably have a very good one again
this year.
Yale has not played in Baltimore
for some years, and the nearest approach to a Yale team has been for
a long time the Yale alumni team,
which annually plays the Harvard
alumni of the city.
The management hopes to be able
to make the Yale game a regular
one on our schedule.
The Navy game is the logical supplement to our lacrosse and football games with the Naval Academy.
Athletic relations are being made
closer between us every year, as we
now have football, baseball, lacrosse,
track and tennis contests. Our
games with St. John's and Western
Maryland will probably be for the
championship of Maryland.
As for the games which are under
consideration, there should be no
difficulty in arranging the Harvard
and Pennsylvania games, judging
by our last year's showing against
them. A game with Georgetown
would be desirable, but not in the
class with the other two, at least as
far as interest is concerned. But
probably the most popular game of
all, and the one to be desired most,
is a game with Virginia. We now
have a football game and a track
meet with Virginia, so that baseball
makes the third major sport in
which we will have an annual battle.

Through the gross incompetency
of Referee Palmer, Hopkins was
robbed of a touchdown in the last
two minutes of the game with Gettysburg last Saturday and, as a result, lost the contest by the close
score of 5 to 3. The game was
hard fought and the Black and Blue
players were keenly disappointed
about having the victory snatched
away from them by the rankest decision ever rendered on the Homewood field.
The touchdown in question was
made by Stollenwerck just as the
game was almost over. He caught
a punt in the midfield and then
skillfully threaded his way through
the Gettysburg players until he
reached the goal line. Just as he
was about to cross the line one
of the Pennsylvanians tackled him
by a desperate effort and Stonie
fell forward with the ball over the
line, room to spare. Both players
rolled over again placing the ball
still further over the line. For
some mysterious reason, which he
would not state, Referee Palmer refused to allow the touchdown, but
gave Hopkins the ball about a foot
from the goal line.
The Gettysburg players themselves admitted that Hopkins should
have been given credit for a touchdown and they were disgusted by
the lack of knowledge displayed by
the referee at all stages of the
game.
Hopkins showed up well against
the strong eleven from the Battlefield town. Gettysburg, it will be
remembered, held the University
of Pennsylvania to a 5 to 3 score
earlier in the season.
Playing was about even during
the first half. The ball see-sawed
up and down the field without
either team being able to score.
Fulton made the score for Hopkins by booting the ball between
the crossbars in the third quarter.
'Gettysburg more than evened up a
few minutes later when Lawyer
broke through the Hopkins line for
a long gain. Gillet by a lightning
sprint staved off the touchdown
momentarily by nailing Lawyer on
Hopkins'6-yard line. Captain Fulton was hurt in this play. Gettysburg succeeded in carrying the ball
over for a touchdown but failed at
goal.
The last quarter was a continuous succession of thrills. Gettysburg gained a lot of ground by
some well-executed onside kicks.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Solon gave to the Athenians the
best laws they ever had, and they
acknowledged it the more with each
succeeding year. But at no time
did his laws please everybody—at
no time was everybody content. I
mean to infer that nothing, no matter how good it is, can possibly
please every one. But I believe
that discontent, and I'm sure that
lack of loyal backing, arise more
often from misunderstood or insufficient facts of the case than from
any other cause. Good things need
not be excused, but they ought to
be explained. THE NEWS-LETTER
has asked me to write something
in the way of explanation about
several, new'features of our athletic
Policy. This I do with pleasure, it
being understoobd, however, that; I
write this entirely in an unofficial
way, and from a personal point of
view. Three of these new features
are (I) the graduate manager, (2)
the press agent, and (3) the graduate coaches.
The. graduate manager means a
concentration of authority and responsibility and, therefore, of efficiency. Our athletic teams have
been increasingly successful, our
reputation has spread, and the
things which must be looked after
and done have grown amazingly
in number. The claims of various
teams often clash on dates, on expenses, on arrangements, and justice to aft concerned means mutual
concessions from, team managers,
but needs most of all some one person who first has a keen interest in
the questions at stake; who next has
Judgment based On a considerable
number of years. of athletic policy
Precedents, and who finally has au-,
thority to make a decision. Now,;
there have, been mistakes made in
the past, and there will be in the
future. But in the past, with divided
authority, there was divided responsibility, and there is no need of comment on the difficulty of fixing responsibility under such conditions.
No man should be compelled to
shoulder the entire responsibility of
a thing unless he has the ultimate
authority, and a place to fix that
very responsibility is what in my
Opinion we particularly need. We
do not want to give the student body
all the privileges, the undergraduate managers all the duties, and the
graduate manager all the responsi(Continued on page 3, col. 2.)

The Historical Library.

THE NEWS-LETTER was wrong

IS

when it said editorially last Week
that undergraduate students were
not welcome in the Historical Library. No such restriction has ever
existed, and the library facilities of
the University are for the use of all.
Two years ago the reserved books
for the history courses were removed to the main reading-room.
At that time Professor Andrews,
in announcing the change to his
class, made an explanatory statement, our misinterpretation of which
led to the error last week. Professor Andrews said that the tables in
the Historical Library would be reserved for graduate students, but
by some it was thought that he
meant that the rooms were for
their use alone. During the past
two years, undergraduates have
been permitted to use the rooms,
but we thought that this was the
case in spite of a rule to the contrary.
THE NEWS-LETTER is not accountable for any opinions which
may be expressed in letters which
are printed in the "Mail Bag." The
writers are allowed latitude in this
column, but they themselves must
shoulder the responsibility. It is
incumbent upon THE NEWS-LETTER, however, to be careful that no
unjust criticisms, calculated to injure the University, or professors,
are published in this column. Owing to a personal misunderstanding,
the letter signed "Expertus," in last
week's issue, contained statements
at variance with the facts. THE
NEWS-LETTER was not aware of this.
We are glad to give space this week
to a letter from Dr. Magoffin, who,
as librarian in charge of the historical collection, speaks authoritatively.

C. W. Cooke, A.B., 'o8, is taking
graduate work in geology.
F. B. Pedrick, A.B.,'09, is studying medicine in New York city.
C. E. Court, M.D., '07, is a medical missionary at Lakawn, Laos.
E. T. Hills, A.B., '07, is teaching
Latin at the Baltimore City College.
Chauncey B. Bosley, ex-'II, is
with the firm of John S. Gittings &
Co. of Baltimore.
Ranald McInnis, M.D., '03, is an

G. Y. Rusk, M.D. 'oo, is assistant professor of pathology at the
University of California:
William L. Bond, A.B., 'II, is a
ection foreman in the Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad shops at Mount
Clare, Md.
Charles M. Matthias, A.B., 'o8,

office for the firm of Malsby &
Sons, lawyers.
Robert Dunlap, M.D., '07, who

on a New Orleans daily to come
back to Baltimore and write for
magazines. He is one among many
in newspaper work who has received his elementary training on

bility. With the -increase of affairs
relating to our athletic management
it has become imperative to relieve
the undergraduate managers of certain things which consume more
time than they feel they should
spare. The graduate manager is
to be a help to them. From him
they can get good advice and suggestions, to him they can come for
their authority to initiate new plans
and carry out old ones, and on him
they can put the responsibility of
it all. I am a firm believer in concentration of authority and responsibility, and 1 believe that they are
the two main factors which guarantee efficiency.
• The press agent also means concentration of responsibility, and
through that better feeling. Undergraduates have written up athletics
in the past, and have done it well,
and have made money by it. But
unfortunately the University has
sometimes made enemies by it. Because the correspondent for one
paper was clever enough to get
more news, or to write it in a better fashion, some other paper has
fancied that favoritism was being
shown in some way to another paper
and the University has suffered in
consequence. Now if a reporter on
one paper follows the teams and
gets a "beat" on another, that is
all right, but that reporter ought
not to be connected in any way with
the University, for what news comes
from any source there must be the
same for all papers, and absolutely
no choice given to one over another.
I believe that the University itself
ought to have a live press agent,
with official standing and adequate
salary, and I feel sure that a press
agent for athletics will solve a great
many difficulties that we have met.
I recognize the hardship that such
an innovation works on undergraduate reporters of this year, and if
no recompense comes in any other
way, I wish that the students would
put down to their credit the loss
they sustain. I have talked to several of our correspondents about

this matter, and they admit both
my claims, that it does work certain hardship on them; but also
that it is the ideal and right way to
handle such important advertising
matter as athletics in a way calculated to benefit the University, and
to increase our friends and to offer
no chances for faultfinding.
Yale has been the first of the big
universities to say that professional
coaching is not entirely a success.
It has had graduate coaching for
its football team, and it returns to
the same system next year in rowing. We haven't as yet a big number of famous players who can afford to come back each fall and take
over the coaching. But we have
a good many graduates who know
the game through and through and
who played brilliantly last year, or
a few years ago. We cannot afford
to lose such men, neither their interest nor their help. And we are
certainly not prepared as yet to do
without a paid head coach. But the
plan is to have others of our older
players (some are out helping now)
give one night only each week to
helping the men who play in the
positions where they played. These
men will work under direction of
the head coach, so conflicting styles
of play will not cause trouble. Several of the men in the Medical
School have told me they would be
glad to help in that way, and that
they could spare that much time
without hurting their work. But
why, do you ask, do I not urge
the medical men to come out for
the team.? I do, personally, and I
wish that several each year, who
can, would come out, and some will
come this year, as they always have
done before. I regret that there
is any class work in the University after 4 o'clock, but there
is; and men cannot miss class work
for anything else; that is good sense
and unquestionably true. Personally, I believe in an undergraduate
team, and I'd pin my faith faster
to a mediocre undergraduate who
is always at practice and who works
hard, than to a spavined, varicose
star who was good, but who does
not like to practice. But until we
have an undergraduate body large
enough to make up a good squad
of forty or more, it is up to some of
our older men in the Medical and
Graduate Schools to come out and
help us in every way they can, especially just now, that a harder
schedule is being undertaken. Fox%
a good record means a higher rating.
These are the three new things
that have been started. I hope and
expect to see them work out most
successfully, and they will if they
are good, for then they will be loyally and enthusiastically supported.
RALPH V. D. -MAGorrIN.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

As librarian in charge of the library of the Department of History,
Politics, and Economics, I think
something should be said about the
article in last week's NEWS-LETTER
signed by "Expertus."
It is well known that this library
is part of the University library,
and that any book in it may be borrowed by any undergraduate under
the same library restrictions that
apply to graduate students. Because of lack of space, the reading
desks in this departmental library
are assigned only to graduate students. All students are welcome in
this library at all times, and will
be afforded every courtesy in the
finding, the use, and the borrowing
of books. It will thus appear that
the criticism of "Expertus" is without foundation in fact.
RALPH V. D. MAGorFIN.
October 18, 1911.

ing resuming lacrosse relations with
Mount Washington. Both "Subscriber" and the editor seem to be
very strongly in favor of having a
game with Mount Washington this
year, on statements presented in the
published letter.
They do not seem to realize that
there are arguments on the other
side of the question.
In the first place we must consider that we are a college, and Mount
Washington is an athletic club—a
condition in which the college has
everything to lose and nothing to
gain. When we play Mount Washington we play a team that has no
reputation or standing outside of
Baltimore, at least among the general public. If we win, we gain
nothing; if we lose, we lose everything by being defeated by a team
with no name. On the other hand,
by filling our schedule with college
teams, we play against teams which,
if they cannot play lacrosse as well
as Mount Washington, at least have
much better names and reputations.
Last year's schedule is a case in
point. The only first-class date
which we had open was just before
the league games started; and for
this date we had a choice between
Mount Washington and the Carlisle Indians. We took the Indian
game, and I think that everyone
was greatly pleased. The Indians
are well known throughout the
country, and they were feared in
Baltimore. Had we refused a game
with them we would still have
feared them, and would have been
ashamed of ourselves as well. We
refused Mount Washington,avoided
the exhibition of bad feeling which
is always associated with this game,
and kept ourselves in good condition for Swarthmore.
I do not agree with my fellow
contributor to THE NEWS-LETTER,
that most Hopkins men regretted
the lack of a game last year, and
I, for one, think that both Hopkins
and Mount Washington can well
do without a game between their
respective teams. Yours truly,
Gr,oLus.

Owing to the prominence that the
Hopkins football team has attained
in the past two years, the students
of the University and the patrons
of the team have desired some
knowledge of the individual players. The football biography of each
one connected with the team follows:
LYNN(head coach)began his football career at Phillips Academy in
Andover, Mass., in 1901, playing in
the position of halfback. In 1903,
1904, 1905, he played at tackle, halfback, and end, respectively. In 1906
he entered Yale and played halfback on the freshman team. In the
Spring of the following year, the
School of Mines, at Denver, Colo.,
made him an inviting offer to coach
the team there, but, for business
reasons, he refused. It was in the
next year, 1910, that Hopkins secured him to succeed Coach Gill,
and now Lynn can be heard any day,
within the carefully guarded enclosure at Homewood, yelling, at
unfortunates, such original phrases
as "You hold that ball like a free
lunch!"
Formai, (assistant coach) first
played on the Haverford Grammar
School team in 1902 and 1903. In
1905, 1906 and 1907, he played on
the University of Pennsylvania team,
becoming captain in 1907. In 1908
he held the position of assistant
coach to the team of his alma mater.
In the next two years, he coached
the team representing Lafayette College. This is his first year with
Hopkins. With his reputation and
his voice—particularly the voice— •
he has his men on the jump from
the beginning of football practice
to the end.
FuLToN,'I2(captain), played end
with the Baltimore City College in
1906 and 1907, being chosen as one
Of the all-scholastic eleven of the
City. He was captain of his class
teams at Hopkins in 1908 and 1909,
and played on the 'Varsity at halfback.
BARTON, '14, began his football
career (still in embryo) on the
freshman team of last year.
BtliT, '12, played on a local team
called the Ardmores, on which also
Played several other youthful prodigies—Gillet, Ellicott, and Liebensperger. He played on the two-class
teams, was scrub for three years,
and now is 'Varsity guard.
BisHor (medical student) has
Played for three years as 'Varsity
guard.
BRANHAM, '15, played with McDonogh School for four years at
halfback and end, and attained the
Position of captain. In 1910 he
Played with Washington College,
being the star of the season. He
is now 'Varsity halfback.

Twenty or more of this year's
debutantes, dressed in Hopkins and
Virginia colors, will sell candy, programs, pennants and other things for
the benefit of the Consumers'League
at the Hopkins-Virginia football
game on November 4, at Homewood.
This will undoubtedly help to
make the Hopkins-Virginia game
the biggest athletic affair ever held
at Homewood by Hopkins. A committee, composed of Drs. Ronald T.
Abercrombie, and R. V. D. Magoffin, Graduate Manager John M.
Holmes and Manager C. Leland
Getz,are arranging matters for Hopkins with the Consumers' League.
During the intermission between
the halves, hot chocolate and other
light refreshments will be sold
under the large concrete grandstands. Attractive souvenir programs containing pictures of the
teams, the line-up and other interesting information will be printed
for the game.
From present indications, the
Homewood grounds are going to
be packed with spectators. No game
in recent years has aroused as much
interest. Baltimore is a great town
for Virginia alumni, and the Charlottesville eleven can be sure of
plenty ardent supporters being present.

Dr. Schuster Lectures.

Under the auspices of the Scientific Association of the Johns Hopkins
University, Dr. Arthur Schuster,
Honorary Professor of Physics at
the University of Manchester, delivered a delightful lecture, consisting of his personal reminiscences
of such eminent scientists as Bunsen, Helmholtz, Maxwell, Raley,
and Lord Kelvin.
After telling something about the
great work of each of these men,
he related funny incidents about
them. Lord Kelvin always got
dressed for dinner in eight and onehalf minutes, because a ray of light
travels to the earth in that time. Dr.
Helmholtz's wife one night wakened
her husband and told him she was
so sick she was afraid she would
die. He told her that that was easier
said than done.

THE NEWS.LETTER
VOL. XVI, NO. 4.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 30, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

NEW ATHLETIC POLICIES

DR. RENOUF IS MISSED

BASEBALL PROSPECTS BRIGHT

HOPKINS ROBBED OF VICTORY

Arguments in Favor of a Graduate
Manager, Press Agent and
Graduate Coaches.

President Remsen's Appreciation of
Former Collegiate Professor of
Physics Who Has Retired.

Attractive Schedule Being Arranged With
Big Northern Universities—Princeton and Yale to Come Here.

Touchdown Not Allowed to Count by
the Referee—Black and Blue
Men Played Well.

Dr. Edward Renouf, who has just
retired from active, service in the
University, has been a member of
our teaching staff since 1885. In
that year he came to us from Munich, where he had been an Assistant
in the chemical laboratory since
188o, under Baeyer and Volhard.
He was Assistant in Chemistry here
one year and was then made Associate. For six years he held this
title and was then appointed Collegiate Professor of Chemistry, which
position he held until his withdrawal
in 1911, a period of nineteen years.
During this time his relations with
the undergraduate students have
been especially close and his influence has probably been greater than
that of any other member of the
staff, except the Dean.
Dr. Renouf went to Germany at
an early age and studied at Heidelberg, Jena, and Munich. In 1868
he returned to the United States
and for a time worked at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
In a few years he went back to Germany and completed the work for
the degree of doctor of philosophy,
which degree was conferred upon
him by the University of Freiburg
in 1880.
At a meeting of the Board of Collegiate Studies of the Johns Hopkins University, held September 30,
1911, the following minute was
adopted:
"Since the meeting of this Board
in June, Dr. Edward Renouf, Collegiate Professor of Chemistry, has,
in consequence of ill health, retired
from the service of the University.
• "Dr. Renouf's connection with the
Johns Hopkins University extends
back almost to the beginning. As
the instructor of one of the most
numerous of our undergraduate
classes; as the adviser, each year,
of a large body of students; as a
member of the Executive Committee, giving much time and thought
to the duties incident to that position; as a member of the Committee
on the Gymnasium, and in that capacity called upon to advise and to
act in regard to many matters of
delicacy and difficulty; as conspicuously high-minded, conscientious,
and sympathetic in all his relations,
both with his pupils and with his
colleagues, Dr. Renouf has contributed much toward the maintenance of proper standards of feeling and conduct among our stu-

Although the lacrosse schedule
for next spring has been completed,
the baseball team has as yet not had
all its dates filled. Manager Meekins is to be congratulated on the
games which he has arranged, however, and it is to be hoped that he
will succeed in concluding negotiations for those which are pending.
The schedule to date is:
April 4—Princeton at Baltimore.
April 8 or 9—Yale at Baltimore.
April 24—Navy at Annapolis.
April 27—Western Maryland at
Baltimore.
May 18—St. John's at Baltimore.
The games which are under consideration are with Georgetown,
Harvard, the University of Pennsylvania, and the University of Virginia.
Hopkins is especially fortunate in
getting Princeton to come to Baltimore. Princeton had an unusually
strong team.last year, and will probably have a very good one again
this year.
Yale has not played in Baltimore
for some years, and the nearest approach to a Yale team has been for
a long time the Yale alumni team,
which annually plays the Harvard
alumni of the city.
The management hopes to be able
to make the Yale game a regular
one on our schedule.
The Navy game is the logical supplement to our lacrosse and football games with the Naval Academy.
Athletic relations are being made
closer between us every year, as we
now have football, baseball, lacrosse,
track and tennis contests. Our
games with St. John's and Western
Maryland will probably be for the
championship of Maryland.
As for the games which are under
consideration, there should be no
difficulty in arranging the Harvard
and Pennsylvania games, judging
by our last year's showing against
them. A game with Georgetown
would be desirable, but not in the
class with the other two, at least as
far as interest is concerned. But
probably the most popular game of
all, and the one to be desired most,
is a game with Virginia. We now
have a football game and a track
meet with Virginia, so that baseball
makes the third major sport in
which we will have an annual battle.

Through the gross incompetency
of Referee Palmer, Hopkins was
robbed of a touchdown in the last
two minutes of the game with Gettysburg last Saturday and, as a result, lost the contest by the close
score of 5 to 3. The game was
hard fought and the Black and Blue
players were keenly disappointed
about having the victory snatched
away from them by the rankest decision ever rendered on the Homewood field.
The touchdown in question was
made by Stollenwerck just as the
game was almost over. He caught
a punt in the midfield and then
skillfully threaded his way through
the Gettysburg players until he
reached the goal line. Just as he
was about to cross the line one
of the Pennsylvanians tackled him
by a desperate effort and Stonie
fell forward with the ball over the
line, room to spare. Both players
rolled over again placing the ball
still further over the line. For
some mysterious reason, which he
would not state, Referee Palmer refused to allow the touchdown, but
gave Hopkins the ball about a foot
from the goal line.
The Gettysburg players themselves admitted that Hopkins should
have been given credit for a touchdown and they were disgusted by
the lack of knowledge displayed by
the referee at all stages of the
game.
Hopkins showed up well against
the strong eleven from the Battlefield town. Gettysburg, it will be
remembered, held the University
of Pennsylvania to a 5 to 3 score
earlier in the season.
Playing was about even during
the first half. The ball see-sawed
up and down the field without
either team being able to score.
Fulton made the score for Hopkins by booting the ball between
the crossbars in the third quarter.
'Gettysburg more than evened up a
few minutes later when Lawyer
broke through the Hopkins line for
a long gain. Gillet by a lightning
sprint staved off the touchdown
momentarily by nailing Lawyer on
Hopkins'6-yard line. Captain Fulton was hurt in this play. Gettysburg succeeded in carrying the ball
over for a touchdown but failed at
goal.
The last quarter was a continuous succession of thrills. Gettysburg gained a lot of ground by
some well-executed onside kicks.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Solon gave to the Athenians the
best laws they ever had, and they
acknowledged it the more with each
succeeding year. But at no time
did his laws please everybody—at
no time was everybody content. I
mean to infer that nothing, no matter how good it is, can possibly
please every one. But I believe
that discontent, and I'm sure that
lack of loyal backing, arise more
often from misunderstood or insufficient facts of the case than from
any other cause. Good things need
not be excused, but they ought to
be explained. THE NEWS-LETTER
has asked me to write something
in the way of explanation about
several, new'features of our athletic
Policy. This I do with pleasure, it
being understoobd, however, that; I
write this entirely in an unofficial
way, and from a personal point of
view. Three of these new features
are (I) the graduate manager, (2)
the press agent, and (3) the graduate coaches.
The. graduate manager means a
concentration of authority and responsibility and, therefore, of efficiency. Our athletic teams have
been increasingly successful, our
reputation has spread, and the
things which must be looked after
and done have grown amazingly
in number. The claims of various
teams often clash on dates, on expenses, on arrangements, and justice to aft concerned means mutual
concessions from, team managers,
but needs most of all some one person who first has a keen interest in
the questions at stake; who next has
Judgment based On a considerable
number of years. of athletic policy
Precedents, and who finally has au-,
thority to make a decision. Now,;
there have, been mistakes made in
the past, and there will be in the
future. But in the past, with divided
authority, there was divided responsibility, and there is no need of comment on the difficulty of fixing responsibility under such conditions.
No man should be compelled to
shoulder the entire responsibility of
a thing unless he has the ultimate
authority, and a place to fix that
very responsibility is what in my
Opinion we particularly need. We
do not want to give the student body
all the privileges, the undergraduate managers all the duties, and the

The Historical Library.

THE NEWS-LETTER was wrong

IS

when it said editorially last Week
that undergraduate students were
not welcome in the Historical Library. No such restriction has ever
existed, and the library facilities of
the University are for the use of all.
Two years ago the reserved books
for the history courses were removed to the main reading-room.
At that time Professor Andrews,
in announcing the change to his
class, made an explanatory statement, our misinterpretation of which
led to the error last week. Professor Andrews said that the tables in
the Historical Library would be reserved for graduate students, but
by some it was thought that he
meant that the rooms were for
their use alone. During the past
two years, undergraduates have
been permitted to use the rooms,
but we thought that this was the
case in spite of a rule to the contrary.

bility. With the -increase of affairs
relating to our athletic management
it has become imperative to relieve
the undergraduate managers of certain things which consume more
time than they feel they should
spare. The graduate manager is
to be a help to them. From him
they can get good advice and suggestions, to him they can come for
their authority to initiate new plans
and carry out old ones, and on him
they can put the responsibility of
it all. I am a firm believer in concentration of authority and responsibility, and 1 believe that they are
the two main factors which guarantee efficiency.
• The press agent also means concentration of responsibility, and
through that better feeling. Undergraduates have written up athletics
in the past, and have done it well,
and have made money by it. But
unfortunately the University has
sometimes made enemies by it. Because the correspondent for one
paper was clever enough to get
more news, or to write it in a better fashion, some other paper has
fancied that favoritism was being
shown in some way to another paper
and the University has suffered in
consequence. Now if a reporter on
one paper follows the teams and
gets a "beat" on another, that is
all right, but that reporter ought
not to be connected in any way with
the University, for what news comes
from any source there must be the
same for all papers, and absolutely
no choice given to one over another.
I believe that the University itself
ought to have a live press agent,
with official standing and adequate
salary, and I feel sure that a press
agent for athletics will solve a great
many difficulties that we have met.
I recognize the hardship that such
an innovation works on undergraduate reporters of this year, and if
no recompense comes in any other
way, I wish that the students would
put down to their credit the loss
they sustain. I have talked to several of our correspondents about

this matter, and they admit both
my claims, that it does work certain hardship on them; but also
that it is the ideal and right way to
handle such important advertising
matter as athletics in a way calculated to benefit the University, and
to increase our friends and to offer

Yale has been the first of the big
universities to say that professional
coaching is not entirely a success.
It has had graduate coaching for
its football team, and it returns to
the same system next year in rowing. We haven't as yet a big number of famous players who can afford to come back each fall and take
over the coaching. But we have
a good many graduates who know
the game through and through and
who played brilliantly last year, or
a few years ago. We cannot afford
to lose such men, neither their interest nor their help. And we are
certainly not prepared as yet to do
without a paid head coach. But the
plan is to have others of our older
players (some are out helping now)
give one night only each week to
helping the men who play in the
positions where they played. These
men will work under direction of
the head coach, so conflicting styles
of play will not cause trouble. Several of the men in the Medical
School have told me they would be
glad to help in that way, and that
they could spare that much time
without hurting their work. But
why, do you ask, do I not urge
the medical men to come out for
the team.? I do, personally, and I
wish that several each year, who
can, would come out, and some will
come this year, as they always have
done before. I regret that there
is any class work in the University after 4 o'clock, but there
is; and men cannot miss class work
for anything else; that is good sense
and unquestionably true. Personally, I believe in an undergraduate
team, and I'd pin my faith faster
to a mediocre undergraduate who
is always at practice and who works
hard, than to a spavined, varicose
star who was good, but who does
not like to practice. But until we
have an undergraduate body large
enough to make up a good squad
of forty or more, it is up to some of
our older men in the Medical and
Graduate Schools to come out and
help us in every way they can, especially just now, that a harder
schedule is being undertaken. Fox%
a good record means a higher rating.
These are the three new things
that have been started. I hope and
expect to see them work out most
successfully, and they will if they
are good, for then they will be loyally and enthusiastically supported.
RALPH V. D. -MAGorrIN.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

As librarian in charge of the library of the Department of History,
Politics, and Economics, I think
something should be said about the
article in last week's NEWS-LETTER
signed by "Expertus."
It is well known that this library
is part of the University library,
and that any book in it may be borrowed by any undergraduate under
the same library restrictions that
apply to graduate students. Because of lack of space, the reading
desks in this departmental library
are assigned only to graduate students. All students are welcome in
this library at all times, and will
be afforded every courtesy in the
finding, the use, and the borrowing
of books. It will thus appear that
the criticism of "Expertus" is without foundation in fact.
RALPH V. D. MAGorFIN.

ing resuming lacrosse relations with
Mount Washington. Both "Subscriber" and the editor seem to be
very strongly in favor of having a
game with Mount Washington this
year, on statements presented in the
published letter.
They do not seem to realize that
there are arguments on the other
side of the question.
In the first place we must consider that we are a college, and Mount
Washington is an athletic club—a
condition in which the college has
everything to lose and nothing to
gain. When we play Mount Washington we play a team that has no
reputation or standing outside of
Baltimore, at least among the general public. If we win, we gain
nothing; if we lose, we lose everything by being defeated by a team
with no name. On the other hand,
by filling our schedule with college
teams, we play against teams which,
if they cannot play lacrosse as well
as Mount Washington, at least have
much better names and reputations.
Last year's schedule is a case in
point. The only first-class date
which we had open was just before
the league games started; and for
this date we had a choice between
Mount Washington and the Carlisle Indians. We took the Indian
game, and I think that everyone
was greatly pleased. The Indians
are well known throughout the
country, and they were feared in
Baltimore. Had we refused a game
with them we would still have
feared them, and would have been
ashamed of ourselves as well. We
refused Mount Washington,avoided
the exhibition of bad feeling which
is always associated with this game,
and kept ourselves in good condition for Swarthmore.
I do not agree with my fellow
contributor to THE NEWS-LETTER,
that most Hopkins men regretted
the lack of a game last year, and
I, for one, think that both Hopkins
and Mount Washington can well
do without a game between their
respective teams. Yours truly,

Owing to the prominence that the
Hopkins football team has attained
in the past two years, the students
of the University and the patrons
of the team have desired some
knowledge of the individual players. The football biography of each
one connected with the team follows:
LYNN(head coach)began his football career at Phillips Academy in
Andover, Mass., in 1901, playing in
the position of halfback. In 1903,
1904, 1905, he played at tackle, halfback, and end, respectively. In 1906
he entered Yale and played halfback on the freshman team. In the
Spring of the following year, the
School of Mines, at Denver, Colo.,
made him an inviting offer to coach
the team there, but, for business
reasons, he refused. It was in the
next year, 1910, that Hopkins secured him to succeed Coach Gill,
and now Lynn can be heard any day,
within the carefully guarded enclosure at Homewood, yelling, at
unfortunates, such original phrases
as "You hold that ball like a free
lunch!"
Formai, (assistant coach) first
played on the Haverford Grammar
School team in 1902 and 1903. In
1905, 1906 and 1907, he played on
the University of Pennsylvania team,
becoming captain in 1907. In 1908
he held the position of assistant
coach to the team of his alma mater.
In the next two years, he coached
the team representing Lafayette College. This is his first year with
Hopkins. With his reputation and
his voice—particularly the voice— •
he has his men on the jump from
the beginning of football practice
to the end.
FuLToN,'I2(captain), played end
with the Baltimore City College in
1906 and 1907, being chosen as one
Of the all-scholastic eleven of the
City. He was captain of his class
teams at Hopkins in 1908 and 1909,
and played on the 'Varsity at halfback.
BARTON, '14, began his football
career (still in embryo) on the
freshman team of last year.
BtliT, '12, played on a local team
called the Ardmores, on which also
Played several other youthful prodigies—Gillet, Ellicott, and Liebensperger. He played on the two-class
teams, was scrub for three years,
and now is 'Varsity guard.
BisHor (medical student) has
Played for three years as 'Varsity
guard.
BRANHAM, '15, played with McDonogh School for four years at
halfback and end, and attained the
Position of captain. In 1910 he
Played with Washington College,
being the star of the season. He
is now 'Varsity halfback.
(To be continued next week.)

Twenty or more of this year's
debutantes, dressed in Hopkins and
Virginia colors, will sell candy, programs, pennants and other things for
the benefit of the Consumers'League
at the Hopkins-Virginia football
game on November 4, at Homewood.
This will undoubtedly help to
make the Hopkins-Virginia game
the biggest athletic affair ever held
at Homewood by Hopkins. A committee, composed of Drs. Ronald T.
Abercrombie, and R. V. D. Magoffin, Graduate Manager John M.
Holmes and Manager C. Leland
Getz,are arranging matters for Hopkins with the Consumers' League.
During the intermission between
the halves, hot chocolate and other
light refreshments will be sold
under the large concrete grandstands. Attractive souvenir programs containing pictures of the
teams, the line-up and other interesting information will be printed
for the game.
From present indications, the
Homewood grounds are going to
be packed with spectators. No game
in recent years has aroused as much
interest. Baltimore is a great town
for Virginia alumni, and the Charlottesville eleven can be sure of
plenty ardent supporters being present.

Dr. Schuster Lectures.

Under the auspices of the Scientific Association of the Johns Hopkins
University, Dr. Arthur Schuster,
Honorary Professor of Physics at
the University of Manchester, delivered a delightful lecture, consisting of his personal reminiscences
of such eminent scientists as Bunsen, Helmholtz, Maxwell, Raley,
and Lord Kelvin.
After telling something about the
great work of each of these men,
he related funny incidents about
them. Lord Kelvin always got
dressed for dinner in eight and onehalf minutes, because a ray of light
travels to the earth in that time. Dr.
Helmholtz's wife one night wakened
her husband and told him she was
so sick she was afraid she would
die. He told her that that was easier
said than done.

Just as some of the Hopkins supporters were beginning to lose hope
Frankie La Motte, the new Hopkins
end, received the pigskin on a forward pass from Gillet. He dodged
Dayhoff, the Gettysburg quarterback, and had a clear field ahead of
him. He had carried the ball to
within three yards of the goal line
when he was, tackled. Hopkins
could not carry the ball Over the line
in two downs so Stollenwerck tried
a drop kick. It went wide. Gettysburg punted, as they thought, out
of danger, and it was at this moment that Stonie made his sensational run, which really won the
game for the Black and Blue. The
game ended with the ball in posses.sion of Hopkins in the midfield.
